questions.text: A graduate student is preparing a presentation on protein folding and the role of molecular chaperones in maintaining cellular protein homeostasis. While researching, the student encounters various facts about chaperones but realizes one of the statements they've noted is incorrect. Which of the following statements about chaperones is FALSE?

options.label: C
options.text: Ubiquitin is the most important chaperones

questions.correct_answer: C. Ubiquitin is the most important chaperones
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Some Properties of Chaperone Proteins:
  • ➤ Some Properties of Chaperone Proteins:
  • ➤ Present in a wide range of species from bacteria to humans Many are heat shock proteins (Hsp) and are known as stress proteins. Some are inducible by conditions which cause unfolding of newly synthesized proteins (e.g. elevated temperature and various chemicals). They bind to predominantly hydrophobic regions of unfolded proteins thus preventing their aggregation. They act as a quality control or editing mechanism for detecting misfolded or defective proteins. Most chaperones have associated ATPase activity, with ATP or ADP being involved in the protein-chaperone interaction. Found in various cellular compartments such as cytosol, mitochondria, and the lumen of the endoplasmic reticulum.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the isoelectric pH (pI) of a molecule is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: The molecule carries no net charge

options.label: B
options.text: Solubility and buffering capacity will be maximum

options.label: C
options.text: The buffering capacity of plasma proteins are mainly due to Histidine residue.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no mobility in an electric field

questions.correct_answer: B. Solubility and buffering capacity will be maximum
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Solubility and buffering capacity will be maximum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: The molecule carries no net charge - This is correct . At the isoelectric point, the number of positive charges equals the number of negative charges , resulting in no net charge .
  • • Option A: The molecule carries no net charge -
  • • correct
  • • isoelectric
  • • positive charges equals
  • • negative charges
  • • no net charge
  • • Option C: The buffering capacity of plasma proteins is mainly due to Histidine residue - This statement is generally correct as histidine residues in proteins, such as those in plasma proteins , play a significant role in buffering due to the pKa of the histidine side chain being close to physiological pH.
  • • Option C: The buffering capacity of plasma proteins is mainly due to Histidine residue -
  • • correct
  • • histidine
  • • proteins,
  • • plasma proteins
  • • buffering
  • • pKa of the histidine side chain
  • • physiological pH.
  • • Option D: There is no mobility in an electric field - This is correct. Since the molecule has no net charge at its isoelectric point , it will not move towards either electrode in an electric field .
  • • Option D: There is no mobility in an electric field -
  • • correct.
  • • no net charge
  • • isoelectric point
  • • not
  • • either electrode
  • • electric field

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pH at which the molecule carries no net charge is called an isoelectric point or isoelectric pH (pI). At an isoelectric point , the amino acid will carry no net charge, all the groups are ionized but the charges will cancel each other. Hence, at isoelectric point, there is no mobility in an electrical field. Solubility and buffering capacity will be minimum at isoelectric pH. The buffering capacity of plasma proteins and hemoglobin is mainly due to histidine residue.
  • ➤ The pH at which the molecule carries no net charge is called an isoelectric point or isoelectric pH (pI).

questions.text: A 3.5-year-old girl of Arabian descent presents to the clinic with severe anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukocytosis, and elevated ESR. This difference can be detected using Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism (RFLP) analysis. Option B) Single nucleotide change results in change of Glutamate to Valine: Correction: this statement is Correct . Option C) HbS confers resistance against malaria in heterozygotes: Correct — Heterozygotes for the HbS gene (sickle cell trait) are relatively protected against Plasmodium falciparum malaria , explaining its evolutionary persistence in malaria-endemic regions.

questions.text: The parents of a 6-year-old boy seek medical attention for their son's mental retardation. Laboratory tests reveal microcytic anemia with basophilic stippling of red blood cells. A thorough history reveals that the child has been eating paint chips from the radiators in their old apartment. What is the most likely cause of the boy's anemia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the interaction of hemoglobin with 2, 3-BPG

options.label: A
options.text: 2, 3 BPG is an intermediate of Gluconeogenesis

options.label: B
options.text: Binding of 2,3 BPG decreases the affinity of Hb to O2 and shifts the ODC to right

options.label: C
options.text: Binding of 2,3 BPG stabilises the R state

options.label: D
options.text: 2, 3 BPG has increased interaction with HbF

questions.correct_answer: B. Binding of 2,3 BPG decreases the affinity of Hb to O2 and shifts the ODC to right
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: 2, 3-BPG is an intermediate of gluconeogenesis: This statement is incorrect. 2, 3-BPG is formed from 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate during glycolysis, not gluconeogenesis.
  • • Option A: 2, 3-BPG is an intermediate of gluconeogenesis:
  • • incorrect.
  • • 2, 3-BPG

  • • glycolysis, not gluconeogenesis.
  • • Option C: Binding of 2,3-BPG stabilizes the R state: This is incorrect. 2, 3-BPG binds to and stabilizes the T (tense) state of Hb , not the R (relaxed) state , which has a higher affinity for oxygen.
  • • Option C: Binding of 2,3-BPG stabilizes the R state:
  • • incorrect.
  • • 2, 3-BPG
  • • T (tense) state of Hb
  • • not
  • • R (relaxed) state
  • • higher affinity for oxygen.
  • • Option D: 2, 3-BPG has increased interaction with HbF: This is incorrect . HbF has a lower affinity for 2, 3-BPG than adult hemoglobin (HbA), which contributes to its higher affinity for oxygen , facilitating oxygen transfer from the mother to the fetus.
  • • Option D:
  • • 2, 3-BPG has increased interaction with HbF:
  • • incorrect
  • • HbF
  • • lower affinity for 2, 3-BPG
  • • adult hemoglobin
  • • its higher affinity for oxygen
  • • facilitating oxygen
  • • mother to the fetus.
